div.l: The person of the towne her fader was
Wyth her he yaue many a panne of bras
For that synkyn sholde in his blood alye
She was y frostryd in a nonnerye
For synkyn wolde no wyfe as he sayde
But yf she were well y nourysshed and a mayde
To saue his astate of yemanrye
And she was proude and pert as a pye
A full fayr syght was vpon hem two
On holy daye beforn her wold he go
Wyth his typet ybounde abowte his hed
And she came after in a gyte of red
And symkyn hadde hosen of the same
Ther durst no wyght clepe her but dame
Was non so hardy that went by the waye
That wyth her durst ones rage or playe
But yf he wolde be slayn of symkyn
Wyth spauade or wyth knyf or bodekyn
For Ielous folke ben parlous euermo
Algates they wolde her wyues wenden so
And eke also for she was somdele smotterlych
She was as dygne as water in a dych
And full of hocour and of bysmare
Her thoughte a lady sholde her spare
What for her kynrede and her nortylrye
That she had lerned in the nonerye
¶ A doughter had they betwyx hem two
Of twenty yere wythoute ony mo
Sauynge a chylde þᵗat was of half yere aege
In cradyll it lay and was a propre page
This wenche thycke and well y growe was
Wyth camoys nose and eyen greye as glas
Buttockes brode and brestis rounde and hye
But ryght fayr was her heere I woll not lye
¶ The person of the towne for she was feyr
In purpos was to make her his heyr
Bothe of his catell and of his mesuage
And straunge he made it of her maryage
His purpos was for to bestowe her hye
Vnto some worthy bloode of auncetry
For holy chyrche goodes muste be spended
On holy chyrche blode that is descended
Therfore he wolde his holy blode honoure
Though that he holy chyrche sholde deuoure
¶ Gret sokyn hath this myllar out of doute
Wyih whete ⁊and malte of all the londe abowte
And namely ther was a gret college
Men clepyth it the soler halle at Cambrege
Ther was her whete ⁊and eke her malt y groıı̄unde
On a daye it happed in a stounde
Syke laye the mancyple on a malady
Men wende wysly that he sholde dy
Fro whom this myllar stale bothe mele ⁊and corn
An hundryd tyme more than he dyde beforn
For there before he stale but curtesly
But now he was a theyf outrageously
For whyche the wardeyn chydde ⁊and made fare
But therof set this myllar not a tare
He craked boste and swore it was not so
¶ Then were there yonge scolers two
That dweldyn in this halle of whyche I say
Testyf they were and lusty forto play
And only for her myrthe and reuelrye
Vp on the warden besyly they crye
To yeue hem leue but a lytyll stounde
To go to the mylle and se her corn y grounde
And hardily they durste laye her necke
The myllar shold not stele half a pecke
Of corne by sleyghte ne bi force hem reue
And at the laste the wardeyn yaf hem leue
Iohn hyght that one ⁊and aleyn hyȝt that other
Of a towne were they born that hyghte stroder
Fer in the north I can not telle where
¶ This aleyn makyth redy alle his gere
And on an hors the sackys he cast anon
Forth goth aleyn the clerke and eke Iohn
Wyth good swerde and bokeler by his syde
Iohn knewe the waye hym neded no to gyde
And at the mylle the sak a downe he leyth
¶ Aleyn spake fyrst al hayl symonde in feyth
How farys thy fayr doughter and thy wyf
¶ Aleyn welcome quod symkyn by my lyf
And Iohn also how now what do ye here
¶ Symōnd quod Iohn by god nede has no pere
Hym bus serue hym self that has no swayn
Or elles he is a fuole as clerkes sayn
Our mauncyple hope I he woll be ded
Swa workis ay there wangis in his hed
And therfor I is come and this aleyn
To grynde our corn and cary it heme agayn
